text:
Crash Course Philosophy
is brought to you by Squarespace. Squarespace: share your passion with the world. I’m Hank Green, and you and I are about
to embark on a journey. A journey of inquiry, into the whole world.
Your world. In an effort to figure out: what gives it
meaning, what makes it beautiful, where its evils come from, and ultimately, what is the
very nature of reality itself. And along the way, we’re going to question
every aspect of your own personal life -- why you do what you do, why you think what you
think, why you feel what you feel. Now, if you’ve joined me on Crash Course
before, you might say, we’ve learned about all that stuff before -- in psychology, and
biology, and anatomy and physiology. And it’s true: Science can definitely help
us understand our thoughts, feelings, and actions. But on this particular journey, we’re going to be
exploring aspects of the human condition that can’t be explained only by hormones or neurotransmitters,
by personal experiences or hereditary conditions. Because, all of those chemicals and experiences
that make us who we are, can actually raise as many questions as they answer. Like, if all of my decisions really are just
the result of, say, how I was raised, and what chemicals I have flowing in my brain,
then are any of my choices actually free? And if I’m not truly free to make my own
decisions, or choose my own actions, then how can I be held accountable for them? Yeah. It’s going to be that kind of journey. Rather than just looking at the world and
describing what we see, we’ll be evaluating it. We will take nothing as a given, set our assumptions
aside -- or at least, try really hard to -- and do our best to see the world as if we’ve
never seen it before. And for what it’s worth, we’ll also be
talking about Batman, and what Dick Grayson can teach us about the concept of identity. And we’ll learn how The Matrix can you help
understand the life and writing of Rene Descartes. Also we’ll try to answer unanswerable questions,
and puzzle over paradoxes that have plagued geniuses for thousands of years. It’s going to be hard, and enlightening,
and frustrating, and if I do my job properly, it’ll stick with you long after you and
I have parted ways. Because: We are going to do…philosophy! [Theme Music] These days, people use the word “philosophy”
to describe some opinion they might have, or the approach they take to a certain topic. Like, you might have a “philosophy” when
it comes to golf. Though...I personally do not. But we’re going to use this word more narrowly,
to describe a way of approaching the world that traces its roots back to ancient Greece,
500 years before the Common Era. This was a time of great intellectual movement
around the world. Buddhism and Jainism were developing in Asia, at the same time philosophical
thought was emerging in Greece. There, scholars were tangled up in a distinction
they were just beginning to make -- between philos and mythos – or what we’d now roughly
call science and storytelling. At that time, there were bards, like Homer,
who were trying to understand and explain the world through stories, while the earliest
philosophers were using methods that were more analytical and scientific -- although they
didn’t really have the concept of “science” back then. So philosophia – literally "the love of wisdom" –
was a new way of trying to make sense of the world. When the earliest philosophers used the word
“philosophy,” they basically meant, “the academic study of anything.” Which, like, I guess could include golf. But at what we might call the first universities
in the western world – Plato’s Academy, and its rival, Aristotle’s Lyceum — math,
biology, physics, poetry, political science, and astronomy were all considered to be philosophy. Eventually, scholars began thinking of these
fields differently -- as separate disciplines. Studies that had strong empirical elements came
to be considered science -- a search for answers. But philosophy came to be understood more
as a way of thinking about questions. Big questions. And today, twenty-five hundred years after
the ancient Greeks first brought them up, philosophers still love asking questions
-- oftentimes, the same questions -- and they don’t mind that they never get an answer. So. What are these big questions that have managed
to intrigue -- and stump -- philosophers for so long? One of the first might best be phrased as:
What is the world like? Sounds simple enough to answer, right
Like, just look around! See all the stuff? Well, this is what the world is like. But the philosophical approach isn’t just
based on observation -- it has other, much more complex questions packed inside it. When a philosopher wonders what the world is like,
she might really be asking: What’s the nature of reality? Like, is the world just made up of matter
and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it is just matter and energy, then
where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is he, she, or it like? And for that matter, when you’re asking
about the world, can you also be asking about the nature of yourself, as a citizen of the world. So…what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Is there something immaterial
about me that will survive after I die? All of these questions are ways of exploring
what philosophers call metaphysics -- one of the three main branches of philosophy -- an
effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world, of the universe, and of being. Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough
for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions, that are
about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which
is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology -- literally the study of knowledge -- the
second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world
really what I think it is?
smry_text:
### Crash Course Philosophy Summary

This episode kicks off a journey into the core questions about our existence and our understanding of the world. 

**Philosophy at its Core:**  Hank Green's crash course explores philosophical inquiry, tracing roots back to ancient Greece where philosophers sought to understand the "what" and "why" of everything – from the nature of reality itself to our own identities in a larger world. The video uses historical context from ancient Greece (Plato’s Academy and Aristotle’s Lyceum) for example, demonstrating how early philosophers' ideas were both analytical and scientific, but also marked as 'wisdom." 

**Big Questions:** What's the nature of reality? Is there something beyond matter and energy?  These questions are central to metaphysics: the exploration of fundamental world elements like existence. Further thought prompts further philosophical explorations such as questions about the existence of God. How do our inner natures and souls relate to the physical world and what happens after death are all points the show explores.

**Epistemology:** Alongside these deeper inquiries, there is also examination of how we come to know anything at all - epistemology – the study of knowledge itself.  The video asks questions about ourselves.  How do our "perceptions" of the world impact what we truly believe it is? 
 
This Crash Course explores philosophical concepts while considering: Why this journey matters; the use of pop culture and storytelling to illustrate complex ideas using a variety of examples – from Batman and The Matrix and the history of philosophy through time.
clean_text: "Crash Course Philosophy" is brought to you by Squarespace. Squarespace: share your passion with the world. I’m Hank Green, and you and I are about to embark on a journey. A journey of inquiry into the whole world. Your world. In an effort to figure out: what gives it meaning, what makes it beautiful, where its evils come from, and ultimately, what is the very nature of reality itself. And along the way, we’re going to question every aspect of your own personal life -- why you do what you do, why you think what you think, why you feel what you feel. Now, if you’ve joined me on Crash Course before, you might say: we’ve learned about all that stuff before -- in psychology, and biology, and anatomy and physiology. And it's true: Science can definitely help us understand our thoughts, feelings, and actions. But on this particular journey, we’re going to be exploring aspects of the human condition that can’t be explained only by hormones or neurotransmitters, by personal experiences or hereditary conditions. Because all of those chemicals and experiences that make us who we are, can actually raise as many questions as they answer. For example: if all of my decisions really are just the result of, say, how I was raised, and what chemicals I have flowing in my brain, then are any of my choices actually free? And if I am not truly free to make my own decisions, or choose my own actions, then how can I be held accountable for them? Yeah. It’s going to be that kind of journey. Rather than just looking at the world and describing what we see, we will be evaluating it. We will take nothing as a given, set our assumptions aside -- or at least, try really hard to -- and do our best to see the world as if we’ve never seen it before.  And for what it’s worth, we’ll also be talking about Batman, and what Dick Grayson can teach us about the concept of identity. And we'll learn how The Matrix can help understand the life and writing of Rene Descartes. Also we’ll try to answer unanswerable questions, and puzzle over paradoxes that have plagued geniuses for thousands of years. It’s going to be hard, and enlightening, frustrating, and if I do my job properly, it'll stick with you long after you and I have parted ways. Because: We are going to do…philosophy! [Theme Music] These days, people use the word “philosophy” to describe some opinion they might have, or the approach they take to a certain topic. Like, just look around! See all the stuff? Well, this is what the world is like. But the philosophical approach isn’t just based on observation -- it has other, much more complex questions packed inside it. When a philosopher wonders what the world is like, she might really be asking: What's the nature of reality? Like, is the world just made up of matter and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it is just matter and energy, then where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is he, she, or it like? And for that matter, when you're asking about the world, can you also be asking about the nature of yourself - as a citizen of the world. So...what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Is there something immaterial about me that will survive after I die? All of those questions are ways of exploring what philosophers call metaphysics -- one of the three main branches of philosophy -- an effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world, of the universe, and of being. Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions, that are about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology -- literally the study of knowledge -- the second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world really what I think it is?
keywords: ethics, philosophy, meaning, nature, human condition, reality, science, biology, psychology, identity, batman, Rene Descartes, Matrix, questions, paradoxes, metaphysics, epistemology, observation, understanding, the world, free will,  ancient Greece, Homer, Plato, Aristotle

fields differently -- as separate disciplines. Studies that had strong empirical elements came

really what I think it is? Like, really, is everything I see and think
and experience…is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then, what is true? And what’s the best way to
go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth,
paths that science can never really travel? And let’s say that, after a lot of searching
and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas -- an inkling about what might be true. Then…how do I know if I’m right? How will
I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn’t blame you
if you’re thinking: “Am I real?” “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go,
these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that
helps frame your thinking around what you actually do -- like, how you should act, and
what you should attach meaning to. It’s called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided
into two main branches. The first is Ethics. You’ve heard of it -- it’s the thing that
politicians are always said to lack? And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply?
Though, don’t get me started on the prequels. In philosophy, though, ethics isn’t just
a code of what’s right and what’s wrong.
smry_text:
Philosophical inquiry examines fundamental questions regarding existence's nature and human understanding.  Ancient Greece witnessed a prominent philosophical movement, with scholars like Plato and Aristotle emphasizing "philosophia" as the study of everything, encompassing both scientific exploration and reasoned discourse.

Philosophers investigate the world's characteristics in various forms. One example is metaphysical analysis, which seeks to understand reality's fundamental nature beyond physicality and existence's ultimate origins (like a divine creator). Questions emerge about the self's essence—whether or not there exists an immaterial soul— and how individual beings relate to a larger universe.  These lead philosophers into a deep exploration of metaphysics' field, examining the universe and our place within it.

Epistemology, the study of knowledge, further considers questions like "Is the world accurately perceived?" and offers various interpretations on achieving truth and authenticity in thought. It challenges if certain methodologies may prove better than others for gaining knowledge.

Ethics branches into value theory by analyzing an individual's moral compass and their choices in life—a core aspect of how individuals live that is influenced by beliefs about right and wrong. This philosophical inquiry examines ethical frameworks, challenging the traditional notion of ethics as merely a binary opposition of "good" or "bad."

Rather than just looking at the world and describing what we see, we will evaluate it. We will take nothing as a given, set our assumptions aside -- or at least, try really hard to -- and do our best to see the world as if we’ve never seen it before. And for what it’s worth, we’ll also be talking about Batman, and what Dick Grayson can teach us about the concept of identity. Also we'll try to answer unanswerable questions, and puzzle over paradoxes that have plagued geniuses for thousands of years. It's going to be hard, enlightening, frustrating, and if I do my job properly, it’ll stick with you long after you and I have parted ways. Because: We are going to…do philosophy! [Theme Music] These days, people use the word “philosophy” to describe some opinion they might have or the approach they take to a certain topic. Like, you might have a "philosophy" come in relation to golf. Though...I personally do not. But we’re going to use this word more narrowly to describe a way of approaching the world that traces its roots back to ancient Greece, 500 years before the Common Era. This was a time of great intellectual movement around the world. Buddhism and Jainism were developing in Asia at the same time philosophical thought was emerging in Greece. There, scholars were tangled up in a distinction they were just beginning to make -- between philos and mythos -- or what we’d now roughly call science and storytelling. At that time, bards like Homer who were trying to understand and explain the world through stories, while the earliest philosophers were using methods that were more analytical and scientific -- although they didn’t really have the concept of “science” back then. So philosophia – literally "the love of wisdom" -- was a new way of trying to make sense of the world. When the earliest philosophers used the word “philosophy,” they were referring to an attempt to answer fundamental philosophical questions that are central to human existence. Now, if those questions aren’t challenging enough for you, we as students of philosophy also have a whole separate set of questions about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology – literally the study of knowledge – the second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world really what I think it is? Like, really, is everything I see and think and experience...truly true? If it isn’t, then what is true? And what's the best way to go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth that science can never really travel? And let's say that after a lot of searching and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas – an inkling about what might be true. Then… how will I know if I’m right? How will I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn't blame you for thinking: “Am I real?”  “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go, these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that frames your thinking around what you actually do – like, how you should act and what you should attach meaning to. It's called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided into two main branches: ethics; The first is ethics – you’ve probably heard of it – it’s the thing that politicians are always said to lack?  And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply, though, do not get me started on the prequels.”

text:
These days, people use the word “philosophy”
to describe some opinion they might have, or the approach they take to a certain topic. Like, you might have a “philosophy” when
it comes to golf. Though...I personally do not. But we’re going to use this word more narrowly,
to describe a way of approaching the world that traces its roots back to ancient Greece,
500 years before the Common Era. This was a time of great intellectual movement
around the world. Buddhism and Jainism were developing in Asia, at the same time philosophical
thought was emerging in Greece. There, scholars were tangled up in a distinction
they were just beginning to make -- between philos and mythos – or what we’d now roughly
call science and storytelling. At that time, there were bards, like Homer,
who were trying to understand and explain the world through stories, while the earliest
philosophers were using methods that were more analytical and scientific -- although they
didn’t really have the concept of “science” back then. So philosophia – literally "the love of wisdom" –
was a new way of trying to make sense of the world. When the earliest philosophers used the word
“philosophy,” they basically meant, “the academic study of anything.” Which, like, I guess could include golf. But at what we might call the first universities
in the western world – Plato’s Academy, and its rival, Aristotle’s Lyceum — math,
biology, physics, poetry, political science, and astronomy were all considered to be philosophy. Eventually, scholars began thinking of these
fields differently -- as separate disciplines. Studies that had strong empirical elements came
to be considered science -- a search for answers. But philosophy came to be understood more
as a way of thinking about questions. Big questions. And today, twenty-five hundred years after
the ancient Greeks first brought them up, philosophers still love asking questions
-- oftentimes, the same questions -- and they don’t mind that they never get an answer. So. What are these big questions that have managed
to intrigue -- and stump -- philosophers for so long? One of the first might best be phrased as:
What is the world like? Sounds simple enough to answer, right
Like, just look around! See all the stuff? Well, this is what the world is like. But the philosophical approach isn’t just
based on observation -- it has other, much more complex questions packed inside it. When a philosopher wonders what the world is like,
she might really be asking: What’s the nature of reality? Like, is the world just made up of matter
and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it is just matter and energy, then
where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is he, she, or it like? And for that matter, when you’re asking
about the world, can you also be asking about the nature of yourself, as a citizen of the world. So…what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Is there something immaterial
about me that will survive after I die? All of these questions are ways of exploring
what philosophers call metaphysics -- one of the three main branches of philosophy -- an
effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world, of the universe, and of being. Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough
for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions, that are
about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which
is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology -- literally the study of knowledge -- the
second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world
really what I think it is? Like, really, is everything I see and think
and experience…is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then, what is true? And what’s the best way to
go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth,
paths that science can never really travel? And let’s say that, after a lot of searching
and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas -- an inkling about what might be true. Then…how do I know if I’m right? How will
I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn’t blame you
if you’re thinking: “Am I real?” “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go,
these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that
helps frame your thinking around what you actually do -- like, how you should act, and
what you should attach meaning to. It’s called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided
into two main branches. The first is Ethics. You’ve heard of it -- it’s the thing that
politicians are always said to lack? And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply?
Though, don’t get me started on the prequels. In philosophy, though, ethics isn’t just
a code of what’s right and what’s wrong. It’s the study of how humans should live
with each other. Rather than just sitting around and judging people,
ethics involves posing questions like: How should I live? Is there any reason that I should treat, say,
strangers differently than the people I love? And for that matter, do I owe anything to
myself? What about animals? Or the earth? And if I do have any of these obligations
at all, where do they come from? Who says? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide
what’s good or evil, as human behavior goes, is determined by your values -- that’s why
ethics is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t
about what’s right -- it’s about what’s beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty, and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically
everywhere, from the media, to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves
considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory, because
beauty, and art, are things we value, and evaluate. And many people who study this particular
kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such as thing as The Beautiful
-- something that doesn’t depend on what
smry_text:
Philosophy's historical roots trace back to the ancient Greek world, where scholars distinguished between "philos," signifying science and logic, and "mythos," encompassing storytelling. These early thinkers utilized a systematic approach to exploring the world, incorporating both analytical methods (which pre-dated modern science)  and questioning established knowledge in pursuit of answers. 

**The Philosophical Landscape**

* During this era, questions regarding reality emerged: Was the world merely composed of matter and energy, or was there something else at work? This fundamental inquiry delved into existential concerns, prompting discussions about God's existence, his properties and role within the universe.  Beyond "what is the world like?" philosophers grappled with questions about individuality and self-identity, exploring concepts such as a soul and its longevity after death. 
These inquiries constituted metaphysics - one of three fundamental branches of philosophy that explored the underlying fabric of existence itself.

* Epistemology then came into play. Its purpose aimed at elucidating how we acquire knowledge and understanding. Questions like: "Is this reality accurate or merely subjective?", as well as exploring alternative paths to truth beyond science, formed a core part of this field. 
 
 **Values in Action**   

Ethical philosophy (a branch within Value Theory) examined how individuals should live in accordance with societal norms and moral principles. For instance: 'Are there reasons why we ought to treat strangers differently than those we love?' Examining questions of obligation, altruism, environmental responsibility, sparked discussion within the field. 

  
 **The Aesthetics Dimension**   
 Aestheticians delved into the concept of beauty. Their study revolved around defining and establishing criteria for evaluation in the realm of the aesthetic. Through art, media, or personal reflection -- they contemplated the phenomenon and its significance, questioning whether beauty even exists independently of our own perception.



This provided a condensed synopsis from the provided transcript focusing on clarity, consistency and accuracy by removing extraneous words and phrases used during delivery and emphasizing the objective summary of information within.
clean_text:
Nowadays, people use the word "philosophy" to describe an opinion or approach to a certain topic.  For example, you might have a "philosophy" when it comes to golf. While I don't personally have one.  We will use this word more narrowly to describe a way of approaching the world that traces its roots back to ancient Greece, 500 years before the Common Era. This was a time of great intellectual movement around the world. At that time, Buddhism and Jainism were developing in Asia while philosophical thought emerged in Greece. There, scholars were entangled in a distinction they were just beginning to make - between philos and mythos – or what we would now roughly call science and storytelling.  At this time, bards like Homer were trying to understand and explain the world through stories; meanwhile, the earliest philosophers used more analytical and scientific methods— although they didn’t have the concept of "science" at that time. So philosophia – literally, "the love of wisdom" - was a new way of trying to make sense of the world.  When the earliest philosophers used the word "philosophy," they basically meant, "the academic study of anything." Which might, for instance, include golf. However, at the first universities in the western world – Plato's Academy and Aristotle’s Lyceum – math, biology, physics, poetry, political science, and astronomy were all considered to be philosophy. Afterward, scholars began thinking about these fields differently -  As separate disciplines. Studies with strong empirical elements became considered science - a search for answers. But philosophy came to be understood more as a way of thinking about questions. Big Questions. And today, 25 hundred years after the ancient Greeks first brought them up, Philosophers still love to ask questions—and they don't mind that they may never get an answer.  So, what are these big questions that have managed to intrigue and stump philosophers for so long? One could perhaps best be phrased as: What is the world like? This seems simple enough – just look around! And see all of it, right?  Well…this is how the world looks. But philosophical approaches aren’t based solely on observation - they have much more complex questions hidden inside. For example, when a philosopher wonders what the world is like; she might really be asking: What's the nature of reality? For instance, is the world just matter and energy or something else entirely? And there are endless possibilities…But that’s for another time! Then, how can an individual find out what exactly constitutes this kind of reality? What constitutes truth then if truth has many facets – and more to it than the simple perception we have in our limited minds. 

How does one start to understand or seek for the answer to such questions? And that is where ethics, aesthetics, and so much more come into play... 



  Now…on with our journey:


**Ethics:*
* This is related, though!  What do you want? How will this help me become a better person? 

Think about it! It's a question many philosophers ask themselves. How do we live, treat others? We can be kind and understanding or cruel and callous…It's all up to each individual, right?

 **Value Theory:*
* In this area of philosophy, there are two main categories. Ethics isn’t just about right or wrong; in fact, this branch is more focused on the "how" of living—what is good for someone can be something different for someone else…so how do we live in a harmonious relationship with each other and with nature?

  **Aesthetics:** (And Art) 
* This branch of philosophy studies beauty. What's beautiful, at least from a philosophical standpoint: How do we define it…and what makes it truly "Beautiful”? 



   It’s important to note - the pursuit of aestheticians—who study this special type of thought—believes there is something universally “beautiful,” something that transcends time and individual perception
keywords: philosphy, ancient Greece, Plato's Academy, Aristotle's Lyceum, science, reality, metaphysics, epistemology, knowledge, truth, value theory, ethics, beauty, art, aesthetics, the beautiful

text:
But at what we might call the first universities
in the western world – Plato’s Academy, and its rival, Aristotle’s Lyceum — math,
biology, physics, poetry, political science, and astronomy were all considered to be philosophy. Eventually, scholars began thinking of these
fields differently -- as separate disciplines. Studies that had strong empirical elements came
to be considered science -- a search for answers. But philosophy came to be understood more
as a way of thinking about questions. Big questions. And today, twenty-five hundred years after
the ancient Greeks first brought them up, philosophers still love asking questions
-- oftentimes, the same questions -- and they don’t mind that they never get an answer. So. What are these big questions that have managed
to intrigue -- and stump -- philosophers for so long? One of the first might best be phrased as:
What is the world like? Sounds simple enough to answer, right
Like, just look around! See all the stuff? Well, this is what the world is like. But the philosophical approach isn’t just
based on observation -- it has other, much more complex questions packed inside it. When a philosopher wonders what the world is like,
she might really be asking: What’s the nature of reality? Like, is the world just made up of matter
and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it is just matter and energy, then
where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is he, she, or it like? And for that matter, when you’re asking
about the world, can you also be asking about the nature of yourself, as a citizen of the world. So…what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Is there something immaterial
about me that will survive after I die? All of these questions are ways of exploring
what philosophers call metaphysics -- one of the three main branches of philosophy -- an
effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world, of the universe, and of being. Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough
for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions, that are
about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which
is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology -- literally the study of knowledge -- the
second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world
really what I think it is? Like, really, is everything I see and think
and experience…is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then, what is true? And what’s the best way to
go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth,
paths that science can never really travel? And let’s say that, after a lot of searching
and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas -- an inkling about what might be true. Then…how do I know if I’m right? How will
I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn’t blame you
if you’re thinking: “Am I real?” “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go,
these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that
helps frame your thinking around what you actually do -- like, how you should act, and
what you should attach meaning to. It’s called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided
into two main branches. The first is Ethics. You’ve heard of it -- it’s the thing that
politicians are always said to lack? And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply?
Though, don’t get me started on the prequels. In philosophy, though, ethics isn’t just
a code of what’s right and what’s wrong. It’s the study of how humans should live
with each other. Rather than just sitting around and judging people,
ethics involves posing questions like: How should I live? Is there any reason that I should treat, say,
strangers differently than the people I love? And for that matter, do I owe anything to
myself? What about animals? Or the earth? And if I do have any of these obligations
at all, where do they come from? Who says? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide
what’s good or evil, as human behavior goes, is determined by your values -- that’s why
ethics is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t
about what’s right -- it’s about what’s beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty, and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically
everywhere, from the media, to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves
considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory, because
beauty, and art, are things we value, and evaluate. And many people who study this particular
kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such as thing as The Beautiful
-- something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something
that’s just objectively true. And finally, there’s one more aspect of
philosophy that I should mention, because it doesn’t ask questions, so much as help us
find answers. Yes, finally, some answers! And that thing, which I happen to think can
be beautiful in its own way, is logic. Logic is the philosopher’s toolbox. It contains
the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers, that philosophers use to go about
answering their questions in a clear, systematic way. Logic is about reasoning, giving strong arguments
that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn, the mortal enemies
of philosophical precision. Ok, so metaphysics, epistemology, value theory
-- they might all seem pretty airy and abstract. But don’t worry, because you have already done
philosophy, even though you might not realize it. You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents, or
wonder if you should date someone, or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham ‘n’ cheese
Hot Pocket, you are doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world,
and your place in it. You’re figuring out
smry_text:
Historical Development of Philosophy

Philosophers often approached problems in their fields with different perspectives than they do today, where scientific inquiry is a central aspect of how people understand the world. The concept of science began to separate disciplines from philosophy and as time went on it became about empirical observation.  Modern academics started asking: "How can we approach these questions?"

The History of Questions in Philosophy


One early philosophical question explored in ancient Greece was “What is the nature of reality?”. This question has implications for what constitutes physical existence, a core topic in metaphysics – one branch of philosophy that focuses on understanding fundamental truth and knowledge of being. The study of how knowledge originates (epistemology) adds another layer to this inquiry. Philosophy also explores if the world as we perceive it is an accurate representation.  Another major question asked concerns how true knowledge is acquired (is science truly a reliable means). What does Truth consist in? 

Understanding Our Place and Morality
Value theory investigates a broader category - questions about what constitutes good or bad, right or wrong, beauty, etc., exploring philosophical concepts of ethics - which explores the human condition and societal behavior.  The branch of Value Theory that deals with aesthetics explores how a definition of Beauty is derived via an analysis of art as well as media representations of beauty.  Finally, there is Logic. 

Conclusion
Philosophers' explorations may provide answers to seemingly trivial situations, like deciding whether to eat a salad or, hypothetically, dating. It is crucial to understand why philosophers ponder these questions as they are in some way connected to how we live our lives and our place in the world.   Their inquiry provides frameworks to analyze and solve seemingly basic daily problem that are not merely confined to academic spheres.
clean_text:
However, at the first universities present in western world - Plato's Academy and Aristotle's Lyceum – math, biology, physics, poetry, political science, and astronomy were considered to be philosophy. Eventually scholars began thinking of these fields differently - as separate disciplines. Studies that had strong empirical elements came to be considered science, a search for answers. However, philosophy came to be understood more as a way of thinking about questions. Big questions. And today, 2500 years after the ancient Greeks first brought them up, philosophers still love asking questions – oftentimes, the same questions - and don’t mind that they never get an answer. So what are these big questions that have managed to intrigue and stump philosophers for so long? One of the first might best be phrased as: What is the world like? Sounds simple enough to answer, right? Like, just look around! See all the stuff? Well, this is what the world is like. But philosophical thought isn't just based on observation; it has other, much more complex questions packed inside it. When a philosopher wonders what the world is like, she might really be asking: What’s the nature of reality?  Is the world just made up of matter and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it's just matter and energy, then where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is their nature - he, she, or it? And if you're asking about the world – can you also be asking about the nature of yourself, as a citizen of the world. So…what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Or is there something immaterial about me that will survive after death? All of these questions are ways of exploring what philosophers call metaphysics - one of the three main branches of philosophy, an effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world and being. 

Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions that are about how we know the answers to this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy – which is like knowing about knowing – is epistemology - literally the study of knowledge. And it poses questions like: Is the world really what I think it is? Like, truly, is everything I see and think and experience …is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then what is there? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide what's good or evil - depending on human behavior, –  is determined by your values—which is why epistemology is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t about what’s right - it's about what's beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty and art. 

The concept of beauty is talked about practically everywhere – from the media to art school, to barber college. But however for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves considering what beauty is, and whether or not it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of Value Theory because beauty, and art, are things we value and evaluate. Many people who study this particular kind of philosophy—known as aestheticians – believe that there is such a thing as Beauty - something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something that's just objectively true, Then finally, there’s one more aspect of philosophy that I should mention because it doesn't ask questions so much as help us find answers. That thing – which I think can be beautiful in its own way – is logic, Logic is a philosopher's toolbox. It contains the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers - things philosophers use to go about answering their questions in clear, systematic ways.  
Logic is about reasoning, and giving strong arguments that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn - the mortal enemies of philosophical precision


  Don't worry – you have already done philosophy even if you might not realize it! You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents or wonder if I should date someone – Or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham and cheese Hot Pocket,  - you're doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world and your place in it; you’re figuring out
keywords: concept,  philosophy, questions, ancient  Greece, Plato, Aristotle, universities,  math, physics, biology, astronomy, disciplines, science, answer, big questions, nature of reality, is there something else going on?, does the world just come from matter and energy, what kind of being am I, do I have a soul, immaterial survival after death, metaphysics, three branches of philosophy, epistemology, study of knowledge, truth, science,  ethical theories, ethics, how should we live? How to act, obligations, values, ethics in human behavior, Value Theory, Aesthetics, what beauty is and does it exist, The Beautiful objective beauty, aestheticians, logic, tools for answering questions logically, fallacies, systematic reasoning, philosophy helps find answers.

text:
Like, is the world just made up of matter
and energy, or is there something else going on? And if it is just matter and energy, then
where did it all come from? Is there a God? And if so, what is he, she, or it like? And for that matter, when you’re asking
about the world, can you also be asking about the nature of yourself, as a citizen of the world. So…what kind of being am I? Do I have a soul? Is there something immaterial
about me that will survive after I die? All of these questions are ways of exploring
what philosophers call metaphysics -- one of the three main branches of philosophy -- an
effort to understand the fundamental nature of the world, of the universe, and of being. Now, if those questions aren’t heady enough
for you, we, as students of philosophy, also have a whole separate set of questions, that are
about how we know the answers to any of this stuff. This particular strain of philosophy, which
is like knowing about knowing, is epistemology -- literally the study of knowledge -- the
second major field of philosophy. And it poses questions like: Is the world
really what I think it is? Like, really, is everything I see and think
and experience…is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then, what is true? And what’s the best way to
go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth,
paths that science can never really travel? And let’s say that, after a lot of searching
and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas -- an inkling about what might be true. Then…how do I know if I’m right? How will
I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn’t blame you
if you’re thinking: “Am I real?” “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go,
these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that
helps frame your thinking around what you actually do -- like, how you should act, and
what you should attach meaning to. It’s called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided
into two main branches. The first is Ethics. You’ve heard of it -- it’s the thing that
politicians are always said to lack? And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply?
Though, don’t get me started on the prequels. In philosophy, though, ethics isn’t just
a code of what’s right and what’s wrong. It’s the study of how humans should live
with each other. Rather than just sitting around and judging people,
ethics involves posing questions like: How should I live? Is there any reason that I should treat, say,
strangers differently than the people I love? And for that matter, do I owe anything to
myself? What about animals? Or the earth? And if I do have any of these obligations
at all, where do they come from? Who says? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide
what’s good or evil, as human behavior goes, is determined by your values -- that’s why
ethics is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t
about what’s right -- it’s about what’s beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty, and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically
everywhere, from the media, to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves
considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory, because
beauty, and art, are things we value, and evaluate. And many people who study this particular
kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such as thing as The Beautiful
-- something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something
that’s just objectively true. And finally, there’s one more aspect of
philosophy that I should mention, because it doesn’t ask questions, so much as help us
find answers. Yes, finally, some answers! And that thing, which I happen to think can
be beautiful in its own way, is logic. Logic is the philosopher’s toolbox. It contains
the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers, that philosophers use to go about
answering their questions in a clear, systematic way. Logic is about reasoning, giving strong arguments
that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn, the mortal enemies
of philosophical precision. Ok, so metaphysics, epistemology, value theory
-- they might all seem pretty airy and abstract. But don’t worry, because you have already done
philosophy, even though you might not realize it. You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents, or
wonder if you should date someone, or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham ‘n’ cheese
Hot Pocket, you are doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world,
and your place in it. You’re figuring out what you value, why you value it, and what
you should do about it. So here’s our plan. We’re going to learn
about the major fields of philosophy, posing questions and considering possible answers along
the way. And each time, we will use a two-step method. First, we’ll really try to understand. You’re not going to agree with all of the
ideas that I present to you – and I won’t agree with them either! That’s not the point.
The point, in step one, is to really try to get inside of an idea – to understand it
as charitably as possible. Then, in step two, you’ll subject your understanding
to some serious critical evaluation – basically, you’ll try to knock down what you think
you know about a particular view of the world. And you’ll do this whether you agree with
the view or not. Why? Because: Only when you challenge your
understanding of how some people view the world, can you decide for yourself if theirs
is a view worth having. Which leads me to my final point: Philosophy
is not your usual field of study. I’m not going to be teaching you a body of knowledge
where success means you know a bunch of stuff. Success, in this course, will mean that you
know how to think.
smry_text:
Philosophical Inquiry 

This exploration begins the process of understanding fundamental questions about existence: Does our world comprise solely matter and energy?  Are there external influences or forces at play? How about spirituality; does a god exist, if so, what is its nature? These inquiries are part of metaphysical philosophy, a branch exploring the foundational reality of the universe and being. 

Epistemology, another significant area within the philosophical landscape, addresses how we gain knowledge and test the validity of our beliefs. Is there real truth in the world as we perceive it? This leads to questions about the nature of objectivity versus intuition or perception, especially when considering the diverse views that may exist in society. 

Value Theory further delves into ethical behavior.  It examines human roles and obligations, exploring whether certain principles should guide our life choices—like altruism and ethical action in daily interactions with others (family vs. strangers). The concept of ethics is linked to Value Theory, examining our motivations when weighing choices. Aesthetics, a branch within Value Theory, investigates the nature of beauty itself, studying art and their objective qualities. 

Finally, Logic offers a framework for analyzing philosophical arguments, providing tools to identify fallacies—obstacles to achieving clear logical judgments in this field.
 
The pursuit of knowledge can be applied to daily life without formal study. From deciding on everyday choices or debates at home, people are making philosophical decisions every day. The course will provide critical thought about the world by examining different philosophies and their corresponding values while challenging preconceived notions. A final point emphasizes that the objective is not just acquiring a body of knowledge but rather developing sound reasoning skills through discussion and analysis.

It’s essential to remember, true success in philosophy lies in developing critical thinking and questioning as opposed to simply relying on pre-established ideas or beliefs about the world.

text:
Like, really, is everything I see and think
and experience…is it actually…true? If it isn’t, then, what is true? And what’s the best way to
go about figuring out the truth? Is science the best way? Or are there more ethereal paths to Truth,
paths that science can never really travel? And let’s say that, after a lot of searching
and question-asking, I begin to develop some ideas -- an inkling about what might be true. Then…how do I know if I’m right? How will
I ever know I’m wrong? Can I ever be certain about anything?! Now, at this point I wouldn’t blame you
if you’re thinking: “Am I real?” “Do I...do I know anything?” Well, as questions go,
these might not seem super…practical. But there’s another area of philosophy that
helps frame your thinking around what you actually do -- like, how you should act, and
what you should attach meaning to. It’s called Value Theory. And it’s usually divided
into two main branches. The first is Ethics. You’ve heard of it -- it’s the thing that
politicians are always said to lack? And Jedi are supposed to have in great supply?
Though, don’t get me started on the prequels. In philosophy, though, ethics isn’t just
a code of what’s right and what’s wrong. It’s the study of how humans should live
with each other. Rather than just sitting around and judging people,
ethics involves posing questions like: How should I live? Is there any reason that I should treat, say,
strangers differently than the people I love? And for that matter, do I owe anything to
myself? What about animals? Or the earth? And if I do have any of these obligations
at all, where do they come from? Who says? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide
what’s good or evil, as human behavior goes, is determined by your values -- that’s why
ethics is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t
about what’s right -- it’s about what’s beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty, and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically
everywhere, from the media, to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves
considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory, because
beauty, and art, are things we value, and evaluate. And many people who study this particular
kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such as thing as The Beautiful
-- something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something
that’s just objectively true. And finally, there’s one more aspect of
philosophy that I should mention, because it doesn’t ask questions, so much as help us
find answers. Yes, finally, some answers! And that thing, which I happen to think can
be beautiful in its own way, is logic. Logic is the philosopher’s toolbox. It contains
the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers, that philosophers use to go about
answering their questions in a clear, systematic way. Logic is about reasoning, giving strong arguments
that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn, the mortal enemies
of philosophical precision. Ok, so metaphysics, epistemology, value theory
-- they might all seem pretty airy and abstract. But don’t worry, because you have already done
philosophy, even though you might not realize it. You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents, or
wonder if you should date someone, or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham ‘n’ cheese
Hot Pocket, you are doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world,
and your place in it. You’re figuring out what you value, why you value it, and what
you should do about it. So here’s our plan. We’re going to learn
about the major fields of philosophy, posing questions and considering possible answers along
the way. And each time, we will use a two-step method. First, we’ll really try to understand. You’re not going to agree with all of the
ideas that I present to you – and I won’t agree with them either! That’s not the point.
The point, in step one, is to really try to get inside of an idea – to understand it
as charitably as possible. Then, in step two, you’ll subject your understanding
to some serious critical evaluation – basically, you’ll try to knock down what you think
you know about a particular view of the world. And you’ll do this whether you agree with
the view or not. Why? Because: Only when you challenge your
understanding of how some people view the world, can you decide for yourself if theirs
is a view worth having. Which leads me to my final point: Philosophy
is not your usual field of study. I’m not going to be teaching you a body of knowledge
where success means you know a bunch of stuff. Success, in this course, will mean that you
know how to think. All we have are questions. And all you have
is a brain. And the goal of philosophy is for you to use your brain to come up with
the answers that make the most sense to you. You’ll learn how to formulate arguments to support your
ideas, so you can explain why you think you’re right. Which, if you’ve ever been on the Internet, you
know is something that not a lot of people are good at. In order to do that, you’re going to need
to understand philosophical reasoning – the tools we use to investigate life’s most
perplexing questions! And that is where we’re gonna be headed the next time we meet. For now you’ve learned about the historical
origins of philosophy in ancient Greece, and its three main divisions: metaphysics, epistemology,
and value theory. We also talked about logic, and how you’re going to use it to understand and
critically evaluate a whole host of different worldviews. But not about golf. This episode of Crash Course Philosophy is
made possible by Squarespace. Squarespace is a way to create a website, blog or online
store for you and your ideas. Squarespace features a user-friendly interface, costume
templates and 24/7 customer support. Try Squarespace at squarespace.com/crashcourse for a special
offer.
smry_text:
Philosophical Inquiry

This video outlines key insights from the field of philosophy, exploring concepts related to truth and its pursuit. The speaker emphasizes the importance of seeking answers to fundamental questions about reality:

* **Truth & Methodology:** The first question is whether or not we can ever truly know the existence of a universally true 'truth.' 
    *  The video explores alternative paths to attain knowledge, comparing them to traditional scientific methods and speculating on their limitations. It hints at the possibility that more ethereal understanding might offer an alternative to scientific analysis. 
* **Value Theory:** This branch of philosophy dives into issues such as ethics, aesthetics, and practical choices in daily life, arguing for a connection between personal values and worldview.  The video explores two main branches of value theory: Ethics, focusing on right and wrong (what humanity should do), and Aesthetics, concerning beauty and art's value within this. 
* **Logic:** A cornerstone of philosophical inquiry is logical reasoning through investigation into the world's complexities and its underlying workings. It emphasizes the role of argumentative skills in determining validity and understanding different perspectives.  
    * The speaker suggests that philosophy should not be about acquiring knowledge but understanding a broad spectrum of philosophical possibilities, pushing viewers to actively engage in critical evaluation. 


Ultimately, the video presents an exploration of the foundational principles of thinking through key disciplines as well as engaging with core questions regarding truth and our place within the world order.

ethics is considered part of Value Theory. But the other part of value theory isn’t
about what’s right -- it’s about what’s beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty, and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically
everywhere, from the media, to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves
considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory, because
beauty, and art, are things we value, and evaluate. And many people who study this particular
kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such as thing as The Beautiful
-- something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something
that’s just objectively true. And finally, there’s one more aspect of
philosophy that I should mention, because it doesn’t ask questions, so much as help us
find answers. Yes, finally, some answers! And that thing, which I happen to think can
be beautiful in its own way, is logic. Logic is the philosopher’s toolbox. It contains
the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers, that philosophers use to go about
answering their questions in a clear, systematic way. Logic is about reasoning, giving strong arguments
that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn, the mortal enemies
of philosophical precision. Ok, so metaphysics, epistemology, value theory
-- they might all seem pretty airy and abstract. But don’t worry, because you have already done
philosophy, even though you might not realize it. You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents, or
wonder if you should date someone, or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham ‘n’ cheese
Hot Pocket, you are doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world,
and your place in it. You’re figuring out what you value, why you value it, and what
you should do about it. So here’s our plan. We’re going to learn
about the major fields of philosophy, posing questions and considering possible answers along
the way. And each time, we will use a two-step method. First, we’ll really try to understand. You’re not going to agree with all of the
ideas that I present to you – and I won’t agree with them either! That’s not the point.
The point, in step one, is to really try to get inside of an idea – to understand it
as charitably as possible. Then, in step two, you’ll subject your understanding
to some serious critical evaluation – basically, you’ll try to knock down what you think
you know about a particular view of the world. And you’ll do this whether you agree with
the view or not. Why? Because: Only when you challenge your
understanding of how some people view the world, can you decide for yourself if theirs
is a view worth having. Which leads me to my final point: Philosophy
is not your usual field of study. I’m not going to be teaching you a body of knowledge
where success means you know a bunch of stuff. Success, in this course, will mean that you
know how to think. All we have are questions. And all you have
is a brain. And the goal of philosophy is for you to use your brain to come up with
the answers that make the most sense to you. You’ll learn how to formulate arguments to support your
ideas, so you can explain why you think you’re right. Which, if you’ve ever been on the Internet, you
know is something that not a lot of people are good at. In order to do that, you’re going to need
to understand philosophical reasoning – the tools we use to investigate life’s most
perplexing questions! And that is where we’re gonna be headed the next time we meet. For now you’ve learned about the historical
origins of philosophy in ancient Greece, and its three main divisions: metaphysics, epistemology,
and value theory. We also talked about logic, and how you’re going to use it to understand and
critically evaluate a whole host of different worldviews. But not about golf. This episode of Crash Course Philosophy is
made possible by Squarespace. Squarespace is a way to create a website, blog or online
store for you and your ideas. Squarespace features a user-friendly interface, costume
templates and 24/7 customer support. Try Squarespace at squarespace.com/crashcourse for a special
offer. Crash Course Philosophy is produced in association
with PBS Digital Studios. You can head over to their channel to check out some amazing shows
like The Good Stuff, PBS Space Time, and Physics Girl. This episode of Crash Course was filmed in
the Doctor Cheryl C. Kinney Crash Course Studio with the help of these amazing people and
our Graphics Team is Thought Cafe.
smry_text:
### Philosophy: A Study of Values & Concepts

This video explores the foundational concepts within philosophy, including its connection to ethics, aesthetics, and logic.  It explains that studying these principles doesn't solely involve accepting pre-defined rules or beliefs; it encourages questioning existing views and forming unique reasoning based on a foundation of critical evaluation. 

**Ethics:** Philosophy delves into how human beings should interact with each other and themselves, including questions about duty, obligations (towards others, animals, the environment),  and personal well-being.  Ethical theories address these questions by considering values and exploring concepts such as utilitarianism and deontology.

 **Value Theory & Aesthetics**: A central part of philosophy is understanding what aspects of life hold value and why. This framework connects to aesthetics, a field devoted to beauty and artistic expression itself. It explores whether 'the Beautiful' exists objectively, and its purpose within various philosophical systems.  

**Logic: The Tool for Answering Philosophical Queries**
 Logic provides the framework for formulating arguments that are grounded in reasoning rather than relying solely on emotion or prejudice. It helps philosophers approach questions in a systematic way and develop strong, persuasive arguments. 

 **The "A-Ha" Moments - Real World Application of Philosophy:** Philosophers engage with these principles not just within academia but in daily life. They ponder issues from personal decisions such as dating to moral dilemmas through critical analysis. This video highlights how philosophy plays upon questions that arise in real life, guiding individuals towards  answers unique to their understanding. 
**Philosophy: A Quest for Understanding and Meaning:** This course emphasizes the importance of learning through philosophical inquiry, exploring various viewpoints and perspectives rather than being a body of fixed or unchanging knowledge. It equips students with critical thinking strategies and analytical skills within different areas of thought and life. The ultimate goal is to understand how to answer complex questions by constructing solid reasoning and forming opinions.  

**Acknowledgments:** This Crash Course episode was made possible thanks to Squarespace for providing technical support, and PBS Digital Studios for facilitating its production in cooperation with the Crash Course brand.
clean_text:
"It's the study of how humans should live together. Rather than just sitting around and judging people, ethics involves posing questions like: How should I live? Is there any reason that I should treat strangers differently than the people I love? And for that matter, do I owe anything to myself? What about animals? Or the earth? And if I do have any of these obligations at all, where do they come from? Who says? Ultimately, whatever system you use to decide what's good or evil, as human behavior goes, is determined by your values -- that's why ethics is considered part of value theory. But the other part of value theory isn't about what's right -- it's about what's beautiful. Aesthetics is the study of beauty and art. Now, the concept of beauty is talked about practically everywhere, from the media to art school to barber college. But for philosophers, the pursuit of aesthetics involves considering what beauty is, and whether it even exists. Aesthetics is a part of value theory because beauty, and art, are things we value and evaluate. And many people who study this particular kind of philosophy -- known as aestheticians -- believe there is such a thing as Beauty -- something that doesn’t depend on what you happen to find attractive, but something that's just objectively true.  And finally, there's one more aspect of philosophy that I should mention because it doesn’t ask questions so much as help us find answers. Yes, finally, some answers! And that thing, which I happen to think can be beautiful in its own way, is logic. Logic is the philosopher's toolbox. It contains the saws and hammers, the microscopes and beakers, that philosophers use to go about answering their questions in a clear, systematic way. Logic is about reasoning, giving strong arguments that don’t fall victim to fallacies, which are, as you’ll learn, the mortal enemies of philosophical precision. Ok, so metaphysics, epistemology, value theory -- they might all seem pretty airy and abstract. But don’t worry, because you have already done philosophy, even though you might not realize it. You do it in almost every aspect of your life. Every time you argue with your parents, or wonder if you should date someone, or decide to eat a salad instead of a ham 'n' cheese Hot Pocket, you are doing philosophy. Because you’re thinking about the world, and your place in it.  You’re figuring out what you value, why you value it, and what you should do about it. So here's our plan: We’re going to learn about the major fields of philosophy, posing questions and considering possible answers along the way. And each time, we will use a two-step method. First, we’ll really try to understand. You’re not going to agree with all of the ideas that I present to you -- and neither will I! That’s not the point. The point in step one is to really try to get inside of an idea – to understand it as charitably as possible. Then, in step two, you'll subject your understanding to some serious critical evaluation – basically, you'll try to knock down what you think you know about a particular view of the world. And you’ll do this whether you agree with the view or not
. You’ll learn how to formulate arguments to support your ideas so you can explain why you think you’re right. Which, if you've ever been on the Internet, you know is something that not a lot of people are good at. In order to do that, you'll need to understand philosophical reasoning -- the tools we use to investigate life's most perplexing questions!. And that is where we're gonna be headed the next time we meet. For now you've learned about the historical origins of philosophy in ancient Greece, and its three main divisions: metaphysics, epistemology, and value theory. We also talked about logic, and how you’re going to use it to understand and critically evaluate a whole host of different worldviews. But not about golf. This episode of Crash Course Philosophy is made possible by Squarespace. Squarespace is a way to create a website, blog, or online store for you and your ideas. Squarespace features a user-friendly interface, custom templates, and 24/7 customer support. Try Squarespace at squarespace.com/crashcourse for a special offer. Crash Course Philosophy is produced in association with PBS Digital Studios. You can head over to their channel to check out some amazing shows like The Good Stuff, PBS Space Time, and Physics Girl. This episode of Crash Course was filmed in the Doctor Cheryl C. Kinney Crash Course Studio with the help of these amazing people and our Graphics team is Thought Cafe."
keywords: beauty, aesthetics, value theory, metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, logic, human behavior, philosophy, worldviews, answers, arguments, critical evaluation,  questions,  life's mysteries, thought process, reasoning, argumentation, internet, learning,  understanding, creativity, tools
